newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS UPDATE- MAY 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS UPDATE- MAY 8.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

--The national economy ministry is preparing to take radical action in national and regional programmes included in the Community Support Framework. The programmes include those for education, labour, health, culture and town planning and programmes in the regions of Western Macedonis, Thessaly, Central Greece, the Peloponnese, the Ionian islands, and the Aegean.

--National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou said yesterday that Greece was a step away from meeting Maastricht criteria and that Greek businesseshad to be bold in bolstering competitiveness in the economy and the market.

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis intervened yesterday in efforts to privatise the Elefsis Shipyards and Softex, the Athens paper mill. The inter-ministerial meeting chaired by Simitis yesterday decided to give immediate financial assistance to Softex to pay off debts to workers and write off its debts ot the public power company and social security foundation.

--Public revenues saw a significant lag in the first quarter, despite an improvement noted in April. Latest figures from the finance ministry show the average rate of increase of public revenues during the first quarter at 7.5 percent, in comparison to the goal of 15.6 percent.
--The General Bank's administration is expected to recommend no payment of a dividend to shareholders for 1996 so as to expand its porfolio and enable it to better deal with competition.

--The Greek capital and money markets are turning into magnets for foreign investors as the returns from drachmas have exceeded those of other European currencies. The favourable climate was helped along by the publication of a bullish Merril Lynch report yesterday.

--National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou ws confident yesterday that Greece would achieve convergence programme targets by the end of 1999, speaking at an Athens Chamber of Commerce and Industry awards function.
--A new study by IOBE predicts that there will be a rapid increase in commercial banks' share of the mortgage credit market, to the cost of mortgage and housing banks, over the next few years.

--It was a burden completing and now it's a burden to process - the notorious E9 tax form on the real estate status of taxpayers has yet to be processed by tax officials and will probably be handed over to the private sector for processing, but not before July.

--Major unions will come to the negotiations table seriously divided despite yesterday's confirmation from the prime minister that he would not proceed to any changes in the status governing job relations without consensus.
